title: English (1869) Devotional and Practical Polyglott Bible (Study)
description:
The Devotional and Practical Polyglott Family Bible, a significant mid-nineteenth-century publication, emerged from the prolific Glasgow-based publishing house of William Collins, Sons & Company. Recognized for their extensive Bible production, Collins catered not only to the Scottish and British markets but also to the rapidly growing overseas audience during the Victorian era.

This particular edition, comprising both the Old and New Testaments, stands out for its comprehensive approach and practical orientation, designed to resonate with families during a time when Bible reading was a central part of daily life and spiritual practice. The term 'Polyglott' in the title suggests the inclusion of multiple languages or extensive annotations, indicative of the educational aspirations of the Victorian era, aiming to provide a more profound and insightful engagement with the scriptures.

William Collins, Sons & Company's reputation for producing high-quality religious texts is well-documented. Their Bibles were known for their reliability, accessibility, and the elegance of their presentation, making them a preferred choice for family devotionals. The Devotional and Practical Polyglott Family Bible exemplifies the Victorian era's commitment to religious education and the dissemination of biblical knowledge across diverse population segments. This Bible not only served as a spiritual guide but also as an educational tool, reflecting the era's broader cultural and educational values.
